TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit Splitter extends System.Windows.Forms.Control

Docs.summary: Represents a splitter control that enables the user to resize docked controls. has been replaced by and is provided only for compatibility with previous versions.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control enables the user to resize controls that are docked to the edges of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control at run time. When the user passes the mouse pointer over the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control, the cursor changes to indicate that the controls docked to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control can be resized. The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control enables the user to resize the docked control that is immediately before it in the docking order. Therefore, to enable the user to resize a docked control, dock the control you want the user to be able to resize to an edge of a container, and then dock a splitter to the same side of that container. For example, to create a window similar to Windows Explorer, add a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TreeView> control to a form and set its <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Dock%2A> property to `DockStyle.Left`. Add a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control to the form and set its <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Dock%2A> property to `DockStyle.Left` as well. To complete the form layout, add a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> control and set its <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Dock%2A> property to `DockStyle.Fill` to have the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> occupy the remaining space on the form. At run time, the user can then resize the width of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TreeView> control (as well as the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> control) by moving the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control.
To ensure that the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control does not resize controls docked to a size that is too small to be useful to the user, you use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.MinExtra%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.MinSize%2A> properties. The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.MinExtra%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.MinSize%2A> properties determine the minimum size that controls docked to the left and right (or top and bottom if a horizontal <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control) can be sized to. If the other controls on your form that the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control is docked to display a specific style of border, you can use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.BorderStyle%2A> property to match the border style of the controls that are docked to it.
You might want to set a maximum size limit on controls that the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control is docked to. The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitterMoved> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitterMoving> events enable you to determine when the user is resizing a docked control. You can use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitPosition%2A> property in an event handler for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitterMoved> or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitterMoving> events to determine the size of the control that the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control is docked to and set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitPosition%2A> property to a different value to limit the docked control's width to a specified maximum width (or height if a horizontally aligned <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control).
> [!NOTE] > Resizing a control using the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control can only be done using the mouse. It is not possible to access the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control using the keyboard.
## Examples The following code example uses a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control in combination with <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TreeView> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> controls to create a window similar to Windows Explorer. To identify the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TreeView> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> controls, nodes and items are added to both controls. The example uses the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.MinExtra%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.MinSize%2A> properties of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> to prevent the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TreeView> or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> control from being sized too small or too large. This example requires that the method created in this example is defined within a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form> and that the method is called from the constructor of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form>.
[!code-cpp[Splitter Example#1](~/samples/snippets/cpp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Splitter Example/CPP/form1.cpp#1)] [!code-csharp[Splitter Example#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Splitter Example/CS/form1.cs#1)] [!code-vb[Splitter Example#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Splitter Example/VB/form1.vb#1)]

remarks.format:
## Remarks By default, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.MinSize%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.MinExtra%2A> properties are set to 25. The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Dock%2A> property is set to `DockStyle.Left` by default.
## Examples The following code example uses a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control in combination with <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TreeView> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> controls to create a window similar to Windows Explorer. To identify the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TreeView> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> controls, nodes and items are added to both controls. The example uses the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.MinExtra%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.MinSize%2A> properties of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> to prevent the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TreeView> or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> control from being sized too small or too large. This example requires that the method created in this example is defined within a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form> and that the method is called from the constructor of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form>.
[!code-cpp[Splitter Example#1](~/samples/snippets/cpp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Splitter Example/CPP/form1.cpp#1)] [!code-csharp[Splitter Example#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Splitter Example/CS/form1.cs#1)] [!code-vb[Splitter Example#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Splitter Example/VB/form1.vb#1)]

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the style of border for the control. has been replaced by and is provided only for compatibility with previous versions.
Docs.value: One of the values. The default is .

remarks.format: ## Remarks This property is typically used when the controls the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control is docked to are displayed with a specific border style and you want the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control to match their display style. For example, if you have a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TreeView> and a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> control that the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control will be docked to that you want to display without any borders, you can set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.BorderStyle%2A> property to `BorderStyle.None`.

Docs.exception: The value of the property is not one of the values.

MemberSignature.Value: public override System.Windows.Forms.DockStyle Dock { get; set; }
Public Overrides Property Dock As DockStyle

member this.Dock : System.Windows.Forms.DockStyle with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets which borders are docked to its parent control and determines how a is resized with its parent.
Docs.value: One of the values. The default is .

remarks.format: ## Remarks Use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.Dock%2A> property to define how a control is automatically resized as its parent control is resized. You can only set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.Dock%2A> property to <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DockStyle.Top>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DockStyle.Bottom>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DockStyle.Left>, or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DockStyle.Right>. The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control enables the user to resize the docked control that is immediately before it in the docking order. Therefore, to enable the user to resize a docked control, dock the control to an edge of a container, and then dock a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control to the same side of that container. For more information, see the example in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> class.

Docs.exception: is not set to one of the valid values.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property int MinExtra { int get(); void set(int value); };
member this.MinExtra : int with get, set

Attribute.AttributeName: get: System.Runtime.TargetedPatchingOptOut("Performance critical to inline this type of method across NGen image boundaries")

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the minimum distance that must remain between the splitter control and the edge of the opposite side of the container (or the closest control docked to that side). has been replaced by similar properties in and is provided only for compatibility with previous versions.
Docs.value: The minimum distance, in pixels, between the control and the edge of the opposite side of the container (or the closest control docked to that side). The default is 25.

remarks.format:
## Remarks For a horizontal <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control (a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control docked to the top or bottom of a container), the minimum height of the area of the container reserved for undocked controls is this value minus the height of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control. For a vertical <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control (a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control docked to the left or right of a container), the minimum width of the area of the container reserved for undocked controls is this value minus the width of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control. The user cannot move the splitter past the limit specified by this property.
> [!NOTE] > If the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.MinExtra%2A> property is set to a negative value, the property value is reset to 0.
## Examples The following code example uses a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control in combination with <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TreeView> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> controls to create a window similar to Windows Explorer. To identify the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TreeView> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> controls, nodes and items are added to both controls. The example uses the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.MinExtra%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.MinSize%2A> properties of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> to prevent the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TreeView> or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> control from being sized too small or too large. This example requires that the method created in this example is defined within a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form> and that the method is called from the constructor of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form>.
[!code-cpp[Splitter Example#1](~/samples/snippets/cpp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Splitter Example/CPP/form1.cpp#1)] [!code-csharp[Splitter Example#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Splitter Example/CS/form1.cs#1)] [!code-vb[Splitter Example#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Splitter Example/VB/form1.vb#1)]

MemberSignature.Value: public: property int MinSize { int get(); void set(int value); };

Attribute.AttributeName: get: System.Runtime.TargetedPatchingOptOut("Performance critical to inline this type of method across NGen image boundaries")

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the minimum distance that must remain between the splitter control and the container edge that the control is docked to. has been replaced by and and is provided only for compatibility with previous versions.
Docs.value: The minimum distance, in pixels, between the control and the container edge that the control is docked to. The default is 25.

remarks.format:
## Remarks For a horizontal <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control (a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control docked to the top or bottom of a container), this value is the minimum height of the resizable control. For a vertical <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control (a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control docked to the left or right of a container), this value is the minimum width of the resizable control. The user cannot move the splitter past the limit specified by this property.
> [!NOTE] > If the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.MinSize%2A> property is set to a negative value, the property value is reset to 0.
## Examples The following code example uses a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control in combination with <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TreeView> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> controls to create a window similar to Windows Explorer. To identify the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TreeView> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> controls, nodes and items are added to both controls. The example uses the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.MinExtra%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.MinSize%2A> properties of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> to prevent the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TreeView> or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> control from being sized too small or too large. This example requires that the method created in this example is defined within a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form> and that the method is called from the constructor of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form>.
[!code-cpp[Splitter Example#1](~/samples/snippets/cpp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Splitter Example/CPP/form1.cpp#1)] [!code-csharp[Splitter Example#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Splitter Example/CS/form1.cs#1)] [!code-vb[Splitter Example#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Splitter Example/VB/form1.vb#1)]

## Remarks Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate. For more information, see [Handling and Raising Events](~/docs/standard/events/index.md).
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.OnSplitterMoved%2A> method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.

block.para: When overriding in a derived class, be sure to call the base class's method so that registered delegates receive the event.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property int SplitPosition { int get(); void set(int value); };
member this.SplitPosition : int with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the distance between the splitter control and the container edge that the control is docked to. has been replaced by and and is provided only for compatibility with previous versions.
Docs.value: The distance, in pixels, between the control and the container edge that the control is docked to. If the control is not bound to a control, the value is -1.

remarks.format: ## Remarks For a horizontal <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control (a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control docked to the top or bottom of a container), this value is the height of the resizable control. For a vertical <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control (a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control docked to the left or right of a container), this value is the width of the resizable control. You can use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitPosition%2A> property in an event handler for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitterMoved> or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitterMoving> events to determine the size of the control that the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control is docked to and limit its width to a specified maximum width (or height if a horizontally docked <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control).

MemberSignature.Value: Public Custom Event SplitterMoved As SplitterEventHandler

Docs.summary: Occurs when the splitter control is moved. has been replaced by and is provided only for compatibility with previous versions.

remarks.format:
## Remarks You can create an event handler for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitterMoved> event to perform resize validation in your application. For example, if a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control is docked to the edges of a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TreeView> control and a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> control, you can write code in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitterMoved> event to determine if the minimum and/or maximum size for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TreeView> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> controls has been exceeded and resize the controls to their minimum or maximum size.
For more information about handling events, see [Handling and Raising Events](~/docs/standard/events/index.md).
## Examples The following code example demonstrates the use of this member. In the example, an event handler reports on the occurrence of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitterMoved> event. This report helps you to learn when the event occurs and can assist you in debugging. To report on multiple events or on events that occur frequently, consider replacing <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MessageBox.Show%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> with <xref:System.Console.WriteLine%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> or appending the message to a multiline <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TextBox>.
To run the example code, paste it into a project that contains an instance of type <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> named `Splitter1`. Then ensure that the event handler is associated with the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitterMoved> event.
[!code-csharp[System.Windows.Forms.EventExamples#550](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/System.Windows.Forms.EventExamples/CS/EventExamples.cs#550)] [!code-vb[System.Windows.Forms.EventExamples#550](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/System.Windows.Forms.EventExamples/VB/EventExamples.vb#550)]

MemberSignature.Value: Public Custom Event SplitterMoving As SplitterEventHandler

Docs.summary: Occurs when the splitter control is in the process of moving. has been replaced by and is provided only for compatibility with previous versions.

remarks.format:
## Remarks You can create an event handler for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitterMoving> event to perform resize validation in your application. For example, if a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control is docked to the edges of a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TreeView> control and a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> control, you can write code in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitterMoved> event to determine if the minimum and/or maximum size for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TreeView> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> controls has been exceeded and restrict the resizing of the controls to their minimum or maximum size.
For more information about handling events, see [Handling and Raising Events](~/docs/standard/events/index.md).
## Examples The following code example demonstrates the use of this member. In the example, an event handler reports on the occurrence of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitterMoving> event. This report helps you to learn when the event occurs and can assist you in debugging. To report on multiple events or on events that occur frequently, consider replacing <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MessageBox.Show%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> with <xref:System.Console.WriteLine%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> or appending the message to a multiline <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TextBox>.
To run the example code, paste it into a project that contains an instance of type <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> named `Splitter1`. Then ensure that the event handler is associated with the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitterMoving> event.
[!code-csharp[System.Windows.Forms.EventExamples#549](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/System.Windows.Forms.EventExamples/CS/EventExamples.cs#549)] [!code-vb[System.Windows.Forms.EventExamples#549](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/System.Windows.Forms.EventExamples/VB/EventExamples.vb#549)]
